original_title: Sri Lanka’s mid day shares edge up
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edged up in mid day trade on Wednesday, as buying interest has renewed and selling pressures and profit taking has eased, an analyst said.
All Share Price Index (ASPI) was up 0.72 percent or 66.91 points to 9,300.31, while the most liquid index S&P SL20 was up 1 percent or 26.69 points to 2682.99.
“Buying interest has renewed and selling pressures are wearing off,” Ranjan Ranatunga of First Capital Holdings said.
The market generated a revenue of 1.1 billion rupees during 1130 hours.

Lanka IOC was up after cabinet has granted approval for three oil companies from China, the United States, and Australia in collaboration with Shell Pl to lease 150 fuel station for each company to operate in local market, Minister of Energy Kanchana Wijesekera said.
However, the share is coming down as there was an unexpected fuel price revision, investors are retracting looking at the short term as returns may fall.
A massive crossing was seen by Horana Plantations, with a 51 percent stake change coming into play, the crossing had generated 700 million rupees from the total turnover, Ranatunga said.

Profit taking has been seen in Sri Lanka Telecom and Lanka Hospitals as Cabinet approval has been granted for for the divestment of the stakes held by the Treasury Secretary in the two companies. (Colombo/Mar29/2023)
